In a small village nestled by the Vindhya hills, lived an Old Man named Gopal, whose life had been one of diligent toil and careful saving. As age began to settle upon his shoulders like a heavy shawl, he decided, in a moment of trusting love, to divide his considerable wealth – his fertile lands, a chest of precious jewels, and bags of gleaming gold coins – among his two robust young sons, Ravi and Suresh. He envisioned a peaceful retirement, cared for by his grateful offspring. However, no sooner had the last deed been signed and the last coin counted than the sons, revealing their true, wretched natures, transformed into selfish ingrates. The Old Man's comforts vanished; his warm meals became meager scraps, his soft bed a cold mat, and his pleas for kindness were met with harsh words and cold stares. He was a burden, neglected and abused, left to languish in a corner of his own former home, his heart heavy with bitter regret.

An Old Man, whose life had been a testament to tireless labor and frugal living, resided in a verdant village by the banks of a meandering river. As the silver threads of age multiplied in his hair and his body grew weary, he decided, in an act of profound trust, to distribute his entire fortune—his fertile lands, a chest of glistening silver rupees, and a handful of precious family jewels—among his two strapping young men, his sons. He believed this would ensure their prosperity and his own peaceful twilight years under their care. They relegated their Father to a cramped, dusty corner of the cattle shed, offered him only the coarsest grains and water, and met his gentle pleas with scornful glares and harsh words, leaving the poor Old Man to suffer indignity and hunger.

There was once a time when the great Mother Star, who held the universe in her luminous embrace, sent her three children – Sun, her eldest and boisterous son; Wind, her swift and ever-moving son; and Moon, her gentle and serene daughter – to a grand celestial feast hosted by the Devas. The hall shimmered with divine light, tables groaned under the weight of ambrosial sweets, fragrant rice, and countless delicacies prepared with celestial love. Wind, equally self-absorbed, darted from one delicacy to another, gulping down essences and devouring morsels with no thought beyond his fleeting desires. But Gentle Moon, ever thoughtful of her Mother Star, discreetly wrapped portions of the finest sweets and the most fragrant fruits in a large, cool lotus leaf, carefully preserving them amidst the joyous revelry, ensuring her mother would not be forgotten.

To him, this humble pot, brimming with its starchy treasure, represented not merely a meal, but the kernel of future prosperity, the bedrock upon which his grandest dreams would be built.
